title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 28 march [1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 28 March [1867]
text: Brooklyn 1867marchMarch 28 th Dear Walti thought i must write A few lines although i am very tired indeed it is evening no one home but Edd and hattie and me martha has been gone to philadelphePhiladelphia most a week Jeff came home last night but mat didentdidn't come they were to come tuesday or wensdayWednesday sure i dontdon't think they will come such a game over me again she has no girl and the work has been very hard on me davis s cousin has been here come the same night they went and staidstayed till mondayMonday then he came again last night but Jeff helped me get breakfast this morning i hope mat will come to morrowtomorrow they think its all nothing i dontdon't even get thanked i have been left so much alone here this winter they leave me a whisselwhistle to blow three times if any bodyanybody comes to break in davis says the watchmen will come over if i blow three times i told him i should be more afraid of the watchmen than i should of the burglars i dontdon't suppose there is any danger but it is very dreary up here in cold winter nights i am most afraid of fire but it will be spring one of these days i hope) itsit's very cold here to nighttonight hattee is settingsitting one side of me and Edd the other Jeff and davis has gone away to be out very late)i forgot to tell you when i wrote last Emma price had been here i got her dinner and last sundaySunday she was here to tea and she came again on mondayMonday she brought me a lot of oranges her mother is very well and been to the theater George was up to day he seldom misses without it storms very bad he is well looks real fat he is in hopes they can sell one of the other houses i see walt by your letter mr Heyde has not forgotten you i too have had a short epistle from him but mine was quite moderate he says he sent me a long letter this last winter but he didentdidn't direct it right so he thinks i didentdidn't get it but i did it was very long it treated mostly about a rabbittrabbit in the wood house i must write to han as soon as i can my arm keeps lame yet it gets up my arm more i got your letter yesterday walt with the money all safe if you can walt just as well as not in about two weeks send me ten dollars i have bought a barrel of flour and am to pay him five dollars and he is to wait two weeks for the ten so walt if you can send it by that time i would be glad) there was something i wanted to tell you i thought offof to daytoday but i cantcan't think what it is nothinnothing of great importance or i could think of it we have got a lot of little chickens was hachinghatching when they went away so we had to fetch them in some died hattie buried one after she covered it up she asked me if i thought it would go to heaven hattie is a very smart child if she had the right tutoring i doodo hope when mat comes home she will settle down they have went it this winter if they never did before walt i think when you read this you lyou'll say mother is getting childish i think very like she is good bie walte dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 28 March [1867]
